review_title: RN With A 15 Year History With Sparrow

cons: In my 15 years with this hospital I have seen profound changes and not for the better. Like most hospitals they are experiencing increased cost and decreased returns. That means, reduced staffing numbers across the board. Eliminating entire areas of the hospital and outsourcing of employees. Changing retirement plans to place the burden on the employee rather than the employer. Increased health care cost for employees and their families, yet only providing an annual 1% raise that does not keep up with inflation. Having union representation that seems more concerned about their relationship with upper management than the employees that PAY THEIR SALARY !!! Using electronic charting and it's data to benefit patients and penalize employees. Not providing employee support and room for advancement. And more importantly not providing the resources to educate their employees to create a knowledgable and competitive workforce of the future.

review_title: With New Management Comes New Decisions and Initiatives
pros:
I do not have 20 years of tenure with Sparrow; however, I have been in and around the medical field my entire life. From what I have heard, Sparrow has gone through a huge transformation in its executive body, and as such, it has really started to make different decisions to ensure it becomes a great community-driven health system--something  I support wholeheartedly. I thoroughly enjoy my job, my work, and the better half of the people I work with. At times it appears things tend to take a while to materialize, such as changes in the workforce, promotions, etc. Usually, though, your patience in the matter will be rewarded.

Sparrow has been really good about trimming the fat out of the workforce. These are not necessarily bad people, just not the type you would want exemplifying your business and mission for community involvement and guidance.

Overall great place to work (although I can speak only for the IT department).
cons: Sparrow needs to be more transparent with its promotional structure and how it gives raises. This process is currently being refined, so I can't complain too much; however, when people start seeing the current system break down with no communication explaining why, it tends to leave a bad taste in everyone's mouth.

review_title: Make sure you have promises in writing - Get out after a year
pros:
Lots of experience. You can expect a baptism by fire and a lot of job duties that can help grow you and your resume. If you like challenges and are looking to expand your knowledge this is great.

Good place to start out at right out of college but get out as soon as you get some experience because there are much better offers.
cons:
It seems that promises are not kept and things that you are told don't seem to ever happen (raises/ promotions / bonuses). Make sure any talk of salary, bonuses, raises, ect.. are all in writing (not email or verbal). Make them sign it and get it notarized if you can because they will give you a carrot on a stick and then take away the carrot.

Sparrow does not reward it's hardest most competent employees and hemorrhages top talent to other health systems because of this. Benefits are only mediocre and 401k perks are far worse than the competition. Sparrow is not concerned with retention at all.

All new employees in IT seem fresh from college because Sparrow will not pay competitive rates to experienced analyst.

pros: Tuition reimbursement, Decent health insurance, Lift Team.
cons: Employees feel completely disregarded and underappriated. The company only cares about profit, not the well being of employees or patients. Pay increases are the worst I’ve ever seen, new employees get paid only cents less then people that have been working for this company for 5-10 years. Only 6 sick days allowed a year, atrocious PTO accrual which is all pooled together with vacation, sick, and personal days. Every department is critically understaffed on a daily basis (the company claims to be staffed safely but takes staff off the floor to watch telemonitors and to safety sit with patients and then count all these employees as “on the floor” even if it’s a lie, causing 24/7 stress and dangerous situations for employees and patients). High health insurance premiums, bad dental insurance, and even worse vision.  Bonuses are a joke and literally unattainable due to the strings attached in which the company makes sure you will not acheive due to understaffing. No understaffing pay for support staff. No Christmas bonuses or perks. VEBA is so expensive that more and more people cannot contribute to their own 401 k. Retirement benits are basically non existent other than 401k. Gathering place is expensive to eat at, with no discount to employees. I could go on all day about the issues of working for this company.

review_title: A small, close group with a supportive manager
pros:
There are some excellent EEG techs that have been there for years and really know what they're doing. I worked there for multiple years and everyone is close. They really become your work family. The manager there can be a bit particular at times, but she ALWAYS has the tech's back, so if you ever have issues with any patients or other staff in the hospital, she will work with you to solve any issues and/or back you up. I felt really lucky to have such a supportive manager. Also the Epileptologists are all excellent and are more than happy to explain the results to you and help you learn how to read EEG's better. 
Sparrow pays better than most hospitals in Michigan, their health insurance rates are low, and they have decent benefits (I have heard U of M has better benefits but I'm not sure).
Our hospital trains students during their clinical rotations, and a lot of the students say that our hospital is their favorite location because we are patient, have a relaxed work environment, and are helpful in teaching them how to perform tests well. It is an environment in which you feel comfortable asking questions and you get constructive feedback.
cons: My biggest frustration was a lack of clear communication about protocol changes. In the last year there were a lot of changes made as our shift times were restructured, and the way we completed tests changed to accommodate requirements from the Joint Commission. Our office often relied on the day techs and night techs relaying changes to each other verbally, but often times things would be forgotten or if you had multiple days off, you would come back to changes and someone may forget to catch you up. I think it would have been better to communicate the changes with everyone via email or at least written communication so that everyone receives the exact same information (rather than playing telephone between workers). It can also be difficult to remember every single little change, so having it written down to refer to if you forget would be helpful.

pros: Most of the people are nice.  Most people really care about the patients and are good at their jobs.  Decent pay and benefits.  Newer areas of the hospital are beautiful.  Convenient location.
cons:
I feel that not every caregiver is treated equally.  Caregivers who are buddy-buddy with their managers receive better treatment.  Not everyone's  opintion matters.  Managers can do no wrong.  Speaking of management, it seems like there are way too many managers at the upper level.  New jobs are created by them for their friends.  And the little hourly people are the ones who are being cut due to budget issues.

Unions are a joke.  They will not back you up on issues. If you are not a nurse, your profession's concerns/needs are not addressed at contract time.  I realize that nurses comprise the majority of the union, but it is unfair/unrealistic to force people to pay dues when they are not being represented.

I don't think longevity is valued at Sparrow.   It seems to make more sense for management to bring in newer people for less money than to pay out longevity bonuses.  But the long-term caregivers are really the backbone of the organizatioin.  I don't think the place could run without them.

pros: Great benefits being you're working for a hospital.  IT staff on help desk is unionized through the UAW.
cons: The call volume is outrageous, and the help desk is severely understaffed.  During the day, you're placed in a queue and expected to take calls consistently with only a 5-10 second break between them.  Doctors that need assistance are rude and condescending, often times berating the help desk personnel who are trying to assist.  The management structure is too spread out - I was reporting to a total of four different people while on the help desk.  More and more duties are being placed on the help desk staff that don't make sense, such as patient room changes and CPAP intake checks - a clear indication that management has no idea what an IT help desk is supposed to do.  There's also no room for growth, be it experience-wise or upward movement, as there are never "special projects" or anything past the basic day-to-day troubleshooting.  Movement higher in the company takes ages - there is a rift between the help desk and systems management departments, with the sysadmins looking down upon the help desk and hiring external candidates.  This rift is actually well known and talked about with management, stating that it's "just one of those things."  And speaking of hiring, the process to get brought in as a help desk agent took three months, which is ridiculous.  One last thing to add - if you're a minute late, you're screwed.  It's like a jail.
